journal-title-group.journal-title: bioRxiv : the preprint server for biology

title-group.article-title: Scale invariance of mechanical properties in the developing mammalian retina

contrib-group.aff: Faculty of Physics and Center for NanoScience (CeNS), https://ror.org/05591te55Ludwig-Maximilians-University, Munich, Germany

author-notes.corresp: †f.serwane@lmu.de; Graduate School of Systemic Neuroscience (GSN), Ludwig-Maximilians-University, Munich, Germany; Munich Cluster for Systems Neurology (SyNergy), Munich, Germany

fn.p: Present address: Institute of Neuronal Cell Biology, Technical University of Munich, Munich, Germany

license.license-p: This work is licensed under a CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license.

abstract.p: Neuronal tissues, like the retina, form through physical forces which induce remodeling over a range of time and length scales. How these mechanical stresses accumulate and relax during retinogenesis is unknown due to the difficulty in applying stress in situ from seconds to hours in living neuronal tissue. In non-neuronal tissue and 2D cell culture, previous studies have revealed that material properties exhibit scale-free behavior. Whether this translates to developing neuronal tissues has remained an open question.

Here we demonstrate the existence of scale-free rheology in 3D neuronal tissue. We probed time-dependent tissue mechanics in an in vitro model of the developing retina using magnetic droplets in mouse stem cell-derived retina organoids. We recorded strain responses to an applied stress across four orders of magnitude in time, up to one hour. Dynamic creep compliance and tensile moduli followed a power law with an exponent consistent with a material just above the glass transition. Our findings demonstrate that neuronal tissue remodels in a scale-free manner, prompting the question of whether scale-invariant mechanical properties are a general motif of neurodevelopment.

sec.label: I
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Mechanical forces, alongside biochemical factors, drive both large-scale and local structural remodeling within the developing central nervous system (CNS)[1–3]. The retina is a prime example, transforming from a neuroepithelium into a layered, light-sensitive neuronal tissue. It has become a focal point for researchers investigating the links between tissue organization, molecular factors, and cellular forces[4, 5]. In addition to cellular forces, the material properties of the neuron’s environment determine how a neuron translocates during retinogenesis and whether it ultimately arrives at its designated position within the tissue. However, it is experimentally difficult to quantify this constitutive relation between force and displacement during retinogenesis as it requires the application of a (i) known force in situ (ii) over the course of retina neuron translocation taking minutes to hours. On a shorter timescale, elastic responses have been measured and reported for living guinea pig and ruminant retinae slices using the atomic force microscope (AFM)[6, 7], and the mechanics at nanosecond actuation periods have been mapped for the mouse retina using Brillouin microscopy[8]. Discrepancies between AFM and Brillouin microscopy measurements have been observed and could be attributed to differences in length and timescale of the mechanical stimulation[9]. At the cellular scale, researchers have quantified time dependencies of mechanical properties using a plethora of techniques [10, 11]. In the case of the retina, and neuronal tissue more generally, measurements of the mechanical properties at the minutes to hours timescales of retinogenesis are sparse[3, 12].

Recently, stem cell-derived in vitro organoid models have provided researchers with systems which complement traditional animal models as platforms for studying the details of retina development. Termed retina organoids[5, 13], these model systems display all cell types and mimic the tissue architecture of the in vivo retina[14–16]. In both in vitro and in vivo systems, retina development starts with an ensemble of neural progenitor cells derived from embryonic stem cells (ESCs)[14, 17]. Parts of the ensemble transform into a single layer neuroepithelium which then becomes the neural retina[14, 17]. At this stage, researchers have measured the elastic properties of its surface using an AFM on mouse retina organoids[14]. The results have served as inputs for mechanical modelling using vertex models[14, 18, 19] and successfully explained the morphological changes the neuroepithelium undergoes before it starts converting into a 3D laminated tissue. Observations within this pseudostratified epithelium both in vivo and in vitro have found that neural progenitors undergo interkinetic nuclear migration (IKNM) between cell divisions[5]. After a period of proliferation, cells exit the cell cycle, differentiate, migrate into the correct radial and lateral positions, and form synapses[20–22]. At this critical step, the mechanical properties which facilitate the neurons’ morphogenic movements are unknown as neither the AFM, nor any other conventional technique, allow probing (a) inside 3D tissues (b) at second to hours timescale.

Here, we reveal the mechanical properties which contextualize the neuronal movements of retinogenesis by probing inside living mammalian retina tissue. By combining retina organoids as in vitro models for the mammalian retina and magnetic droplets as in situ mechanical actuators[23], we were able to measure the time dependent mechanical properties on timescales from seconds to hours, and carry out mechanical characterizations over multiple days of development.

sec.label: A
sec.title: Probing long-term mechanics in a mammalian retina organoid
sec.p: To grow an in vitro model of the mammalian retina, we followed an established protocol for generating retina organoids from mouse embryonic stem cells (ESCs) (Fig. 1a; Methods)[14, 24]. The Rx-GFP line provides a fluorescence-based readout for the differentiation into retina cells types as GFP is expressed under the retina tissue specific promoter Rx[14]. We confirmed development of photoreceptor cells by recoverin immunostaining and confocal microscopy imaging in organoids from the first round of culture in which we collected mechanical measurements (Fig. 1b; Suppl. Movie 1, Methods).

We applied a carefully calibrated stress dipole to the retina tissue using magnetically responsive droplets, building on our previous experiments in non-neuronal systems[23, 25], as detailed in Methods. Previous implementations of the technology relied on the measurement of the ferrofluid magnetization curve as well as the magnetic field. Both required specialized equipment such as a superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID)[23]. Here, we calibrated the applied stresses purely using Newtonian fluids with known viscosity as a standard, making the technology accessible to other researchers (Methods). To improve analysis, we developed a python-based open source software package for data analysis with a graphical user interface (GUI) and made it available to the community (https://github.com/serwane/retina_mechanics, Methods, Suppl. Fig. 1). To reliably quantify tissue strain along arbitrary directions within the imaging plane we optimized the strain readout and image segmentation (Methods, Suppl. Note 1). Taken together, these improvements allowed us to perform hour-long compliance measurements with high fidelity. We injected droplets with radii between 9 and 26 microns which were both magnetic and fluorescent[26] into retina regions which we identified via the fluorescence signal (Fig. 1c and Methods). Following an injection, we incubated the organoid for several hours and then performed live-imaging (Methods). For each measurement, we confirmed that the droplet was situated inside the thin (up to 100 microns) retina layer (Suppl. Movie 1) using confocal microscopy (Fig. 1d). We collected time series of confocal sections before and during the application of stress (Fig. 1e, Suppl. Movie 2, Methods), and quantified the droplet’s aspect ratio b/a and relative orientation θ at every time point using an elliptical segmentation (Fig. 1e,f, Methods). From the aspect ratio and orientation of the droplet we calculated the strain as (1)ε=(ba)2/3(sin2θ(ba)2+cos2θ)−1/2−1 [27]. Since the droplets were strained uniaxially, we obtained the effective tensile creep compliance along an arbitrary direction as (2)J(t)=ε(t)−ε0σ, where ε0 is the average strain before the application of the magnetic field and σ is the magnitude of the applied magnetic stress introduced at t = 0.

To study material properties in the early stages of retina development, we measured J (t) using organoids from three independent experiment rounds and on days in vitro (DIV) ranging from 16 to 24. Within this time period, retina progenitor cells differentiate into the major cell types, including ganglion cells, horizontal cells, cones, amacrine cells, rods, and bipolar cells[17]. The retina becomes laminated, organizing the different neurons into distinct layers. DIV 20 corresponds to the day of birth of the mouse[17].

sec.label: B
sec.title: Retina tissue remodels in a scale-free manner
sec.p: We applied stresses and measured the compliance for a duration of up to 1 hour with a temporal resolution of 1.5 seconds (Fig. 1j). One intriguing finding is that, when forces are applied within the retina tissue, the creep compliance shows a scale-free behaviour across 4 orders of magnitude. We found this power law scaling with respect to time for all our measurements across organoid days and rounds (Fig 2a). The quality of the power law fit is excellent, with R2 values above 0.95 for 15 of 16 measurements (Fig. 2a, Methods). To model such a system using a simplistic mechanical circuit we used a single fractional-order linear viscoelastic element called a springpot[28]. The springpot is fully described by just two parameters, β and cβ, and provides the creep compliance as[29] (3)J(t)=1cβΓ(1+β)tβ where Γ is the Gamma-function. The dimensionless scaling exponent β tunes the response of the element from purely elastic, β = 0, to purely fluid, β = 1, with intermediate values describing the relative fluidity of the viscoelastic response. The parameter cβ has units of Pa·sβ, reflecting the magnitude of viscoelastic resistance to displacement and flow. From fittings to the compliance data (Methods), we found β = 0.14 ± 0.05 (mean ± s.d.) and cβ=1.52−0.63+1.06kPa⋅sβ¯ (geometric mean, geometric s.d.). These values for β demonstrate that the retina tissue, while still viscoelastic, is more solid-like than fluid-like (Fig. 2b).

The elegance of the springpot model is that it provides analytical solutions for the frequency dependence of the effective tensile storage and loss modulus. This allow us to calculate their magnitude from the experimentally determined values of β and cβ at various frequencies (Fig. 2c). Since β < 0.5, the storage modulus always dominates over the loss modulus (Fig. 2c), highlighting the elastic behaviour. We find a scaling of the tensile storage and loss modulus as E′ ∝ ωβ and E′′ ∝ ωβ, respectively. This scaling behaviour together with the magnitude of β are consistent with the properties of a soft glassy material above the glass transition as discussed by Sollich and coauthors[30].

sec.label: C
sec.title: Quantifying mechanics on the timescales of retinogenesis
sec.p: We quantified the effective Young’s modulus and viscosity of the neurons’ environment at the scales relevant to retinogenesis, including the time and length scales of interkinetic nuclear migration, cell division, and differentiation as depicted in Fig. 3a. From the effective tensile storage and loss modulus, we calculated the Young’s modulus, E, and dynamic viscosity, η, for timescales τ = 2π/ω from 1 to 104 seconds. (Fig. 3b,c, Methods). Evaluated at the timescale of one second, we found the geometric average of Young’s moduli across all organoids to be 0.80−0.36+0.64 kPa, in excellent agreement with values obtained from the bulk modulus of the guinea pig and the mouse retina determined via the AFM[6, 9].

Based on the springpot model, the Young’s modulus scales as E ∝ τ −β. Using the experimentally determined values for β and cβ we found the elastic modulus decreases to 0.21−0.06+0.09 kPa at 104 seconds. Thus, the tissue becomes softer. For small values of β, the viscosity shows a much stronger timescale dependence, scaling as τ 1−β, implying an increase from 9.0−5.8+16.2 Pa·s at 1 second to 24−11+20 kPa·s at 104 seconds. The tissue becomes effectively more viscous for longer observation times which might directly affect the ability of neurons to navigate their micro-environment to reach their final destination.

sec.label: III
sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our measurements of strain responses in mammalian retinal tissue (Fig. 1) revealed a previously unrecognized scale-free rheology in neuronal tissue. We recorded power law scaling in tissue compliance over time, indicating remodeling across timescales from seconds to hours (Fig. 2). Using a minimalistic theoretical model [28], we quantified the effective Young’s modulus and the dynamic viscosity across timescales (Fig. 3), unveiling new insights into developmental mechanics. While power law rheology has been observed in single cells and non-neuronal tissue, discovering scale-free rheology in neuronal tissue has implications for understanding the physical principles of development in the retina and brain.

Researchers have long speculated about the role of time-dependence in material properties in developing 3D neuronal tissue. However, time-independent parameters like Young’s modulus (stiffness) and dynamic viscosity have been the primary experimentally accessible and reported measures[3, 10]. Our measurements recapitulate prior characterizations of retina mechanics at seconds timescale while offering a key advance: a rheology describing remodeling mechanics across 4 orders of magnitude, up to hour timescales. Our data show that the effective Young’s modulus decreases by fourfold, while the effective dynamic viscosity increases by over three orders of magnitude. By modeling viscoelastic mechanics with a two-parameter power law, our work encourages the adoption of fractional-order rheology as a more elegant and accurate approach to nervous tissue mechanics. How time-dependent material properties affect neuronal network formation has remained an open question which can now be tackled. In vivo studies in Xenopus show that axon growth is regulated by environmental stiffness, with a Young’s modulus around 0.6 kPa characterized at seconds timescale[1]. Meanwhile, cell culture studies indicate that synapse formation occurs over minutes to hours[31] highlighting the need for measurements and theoretical models bridging these timescales. The fractional-order model we implement here combined with experimental characterization bridges this gap and advances mechanobiology by clarifying the role of time-dependent material properties in neurogenesis[21].

Our measurements compel us to reconceptualize the forming retina as an amorphous material near the glass transition. Indications of soft glassy rheology (SGR) have been shown via the recording of cell dynamics in 2D cell culture[32] and in 3D in non-neuronal tissues[33, 34]. We measured a scaling of the storage and loss modulus as ωβ with β = 0.14 which is consistent with a soft glassy material near and above the glass transition[30, 33, 35]. We recapitulate findings in 2D cell culture where power law scaling at subcellular scale has been reported[35–37]. Magnetic tweezer experiments on the cytoskeleton of various cell lines found β ∈ [0.17, 0.25][35, 36, 38], comparable with what we report here at completely different length and time scales in 3D neuronal tissue. We hypothesize that a glassy material just above its glass transition is the way to balance the competing engineering goals of retina development: maximizing retina imaging resolution requires a dense, regular packing of neurons; at the same time, tissue growth necessitates the dynamic refinement of the architecture. We observe a relatively small spread in the measurements of the scaling exponent β (Fig. 2b). We speculate β to be a tightly regulated physical property of the tissue, even in the presence of relatively large heterogeneities in absolute stiffness in various biological replicates. Whether the scaling behaviour is reminiscent only of retina tissue or a general hallmark of other neuronal systems is an open question which could be explored by applying the concepts presented here in other organoid systems.

We have shown that magnetic droplets, combined with stem cell-derived organoids, provide unprecedented insights into the mechanics of previously inaccessible tissues. By showing how to calibrate ferrofluid droplets as force actuators without specialized equipment and sharing our Python-based analysis pipeline with a GUI, we lower the experimental hurdle for mechanobiology researchers to adopt and build on this technology. This approach can be easily adapted to study mechanics of various human organoid systems, including human cerebral organoids.

Direct experimental measurements are critical for elucidating how physical properties of the tissue emerge from interactions at the cellular level. In this context, our work informs recent theoretical vertex models with experimentally measured parameters. Notably, vertex models successfully capture a jamming-unjamming transition in epithelial sheets [39]. A jamming transition has been shown experimentally in non-neuronal tissues [25, 40, 41], and inferred in the non-mammalian retina from imaging of tissue architecture [42]. Here, we provide the first direct quantification of neuronal tissue mechanics over timescales from seconds to hours, uncovering a scaling of both storage and loss modulus with ωβ that challenges predictions from recent 3D vertex models [43, 44].

This discovery of scale-free rheology in neuronal tissue brings concepts developed in the soft matter physics community into the purview of developmental and neurobiologists. Mechanics are recognized to play crucial roles in many aspects of the nervous system, including development, homeostasis, and disease[3]. However, most mechanical characterizations have measured at timescales of seconds or shorter. Understanding how forces drive cellular and tissue scale remodeling during neurogenesis requires a mechanical description on longer timescales. The scale-free description of neuronal mechanics as introduced here could be the key to unlocking its role in processes ranging from migration and proliferation, to cortex folding and synapse function.

sec.title: Stem cell culture and retina organoid generation
sec.p: We generated organoids from mouse embryonic stem cells in three independent rounds. For each round, we thawed Rx-GFP K/I EB5 cells (AES0145, RIKEN) from LN2 storage at passages 26, 23, and 23, respectively, and maintained them for two passages according to a previously published protocol[14, 24] prior to retina differentiation. We seeded 3 × 103 cells per well in 100 µl volumes in 96-well round bottom plates on DIV 0 and added 2% Matrigel on DIV 1. We cultured organoids at 20% O2 until DIV 7, before transferring to Petri dishes for further culture in retina maturation medium 1 at 40% O2. On DIV 10, we transferred organoids to new dishes containing retina maintenance media 2 (RMM2). We supplemented RMM2 with 0.5 µM EC23 from DIV 10-14 and with 1 mM taurine from DIV 10. On DIV 14, we screened retina organoids for GFP under a Nikon SMZ25 stereoscope with a 0.5X SHR Plan Apo objective and fluorescence illumination and transferred GFP-positive organoids intact (without trisection) to new dishes with fresh media. We maintained organoids up to DIV 26, removing and replacing half of the media on DIV 16, 18, 21, 23, and 25.

sec.title: Immunohistochemistry
sec.p: A selection of organoids from the first round of culture in which we made mechanical measurements were fixed in 4% PFA for 60 minutes on an orbital shaker at 4°C. Following fixation, organoids were rinsed three times in PBS. After four days in PBS at 4°C, organoids were transferred to 30% sucrose and held overnight at 4°C, before being embedding and frozen in optimal cutting temperature compound. Organoids were cut into 10-30 micron thick sections on a cryotome (CryoStar NX70). Sections were held at 4°C prior to staining. We performed immunohistochemistry using recoverin Rabbit IgG (1:500) and goat anti-rabbit AF568(1:500)(Merck Millipore AB5585). We blocked sections (90% PBST; T = TritonX 0.5% and 10% NGS) for 1 hour at room temperature. Following a PBS rinse, we incubated sections in primary antibody overnight at 4°C and in secondary antibody for 4 hours at room temperature, with PBS rinses between and afterwards. Finally, we stained sections with Nucspot650 (Biotium) (1:500) for 30 minutes before a final wash. We mounted sections in FlourmountG on a glass cover slip and stored samples at 4°C.

sec.title: Preparation and injection of ferrofluid
sec.p: We prepared magnetic oil for injection experiments from a 1:1 (v/v) mixture of 0.2 micron filtered DFF2 (Ferrotec) and Fluorinert FC40 (FL-005-HP-1000, 3M) with 2.5 wt.% 008-FluoroSurfactant (RAN Biotechnologies) and 250 µM F86Cy5[26]. To control the concentration of DFF2 across multiple rounds and to compensate evaporation, we stored the magnetic oil at 4°C and thinned it with Fluorinert FC40 as needed. Prior to injection, we sonicated the magnetic oil for 10 minutes at room temperature before loading it into a 55 mm long straight spiked 10 micron ID ICSI-Pipette (BM100T-10P, BioMedical Instruments).

We injected organoids with ferrofluid droplets under a Nikon SMZ25 stereoscope (see above) on agarose under RMM2 media. Immediately after organoid injection, we injected ferrofluid into N190000 viscous standards (Cannon Instrument Company) to calibrate the applied stress (Suppl. Information).

sec.title: Imaging of living and fixed organoids
sec.p: Prior to injection, we acquired fluorescence and phase contrast images in Fig. 1a using a Ximea xiC camera mounted to a Zeiss Axiovert 200M inverted fluorescence microscope with condenser. After droplet injection, we maintained organoids at 37°C in a humidified 5% CO2 40% O2 environment for approximately 4 hours. For live imaging, we placed organoids within a silicone well sandwiched between two glass coverslips and filled with supplemented RMM2 before transferring to the 37°C live imaging chamber (Digital Pixel). We performed all confocal microscopy on a Zeiss LSM 980. We imaged the fixed section in Fig. 1b with a C-Achroplan 32x/0.85 water immersion objective. We imaged droplets in stress calibration measurements in viscous standards with the A-Plan 10x/0.25 air objective and the droplets for mechanical measurements in organoids with either the Plan-Apochromat 20x/0.8 M27 air objective or the LD LCI Plan-Apochromat 40x/1.2 Imm Korr DIC M27 objective. We acquired all time series at a rate of 1 frame per 1.5 seconds and frame scan time of 0.2 seconds. To improve visibility for the reader in Fig. 1e, we used Fiji to sum images from a mechanical measurement time series (DIV 19, Fig. 1f,g and Fig. 2a) across 10 frames.

sec.title: Application of magnetic stress
sec.p: We applied a step change in stress to the magnetic droplet by rapidly moving a Hallbach array of permanent magnets mounted to a LabVIEW controlled linear stage, as previously described[23], from an initial position far from the droplet (low stress, σm = σ0) to a final position close to the droplet (high stress, σm = σ0 + σ), while imaging the droplet with confocal microscopy. In order to determine the orientation, timing, and magnitude of the applied stress in the organoid, we applied the same magnetic field to droplets in viscous standards (N190000, Cannon Instrument Company) at (37 ± 0.1)°C.

sec.title: Calculation of strain
sec.p: In the absence of other stresses, the droplet strain under a uniaxial stress is ε = (b/a)2/3 − 1. When other stresses may be present in the tissue, the droplet shows a non-zero initial deformation. To calculate the strain in the direction of the applied field in the presence of pre-deformations we use the droplet’s aspect ratio, b/a, and declination, θ, relative to the magnetic field (Figure 1e). We measured the magnetic field orientation from the alignment of the elliptical segmentation of the droplet at maximal strain in calibration measurements. Following the example of [27], it can be shown that the angle-corrected strain along an arbitrary axis is given by ε=(ba)2/3(sin2θ(ba)2+cos2θ)−1/2−1. A full derivation can be found in Suppl. Note 1.

sec.title: A python-based user-friendly interface for droplet shape analysis and fitting
sec.p: To be able to perform calibrations, image processing and analysis efficiently on long time series we developed a python-based user interface using libraries like NumPy, SciPy, and OpenCV. The pipeline consists of three main tabs - analyzing, calibrating, and fitting. For a screenshot, see Suppl. Fig. 1. The graphical user interface (GUI) allows users to fit ellipses to droplet images from time-lapse sequences. This process generates strain curves, which are used in a next step to extract the material’s mechanical properties. The software is programmed in a modular way using separate classes for the GUI, image analysis, and fitting algorithms. The fitting algorithm uses the curve_fit function from SciPy [45] to model pre-magnetic and the magnetic field phase (creep). The best fit is selected based on minimal residuals by iterating 100 times over statistically varied initial conditions. The pipeline also features error propagation using the uncertainties [46] package, providing uncertainty estimations for fit parameters. A calibration measurement routine ensures the accuracy of the applied stress by accounting for experimental errors, including fitting errors and errors in the measurement of the viscous standards.

sec.title: Modeling organoid mechanics
sec.p: We modelled the mechanical response of the droplet in the organoid as a single spring-pot element characterized by the two parameters β and cβ giving the creep compliance J(t)=1cβΓ(1+β)tβ. We obtained β and cβ from a linear fit to the log transformed time and compliance data. In contrast to the Kelvin-Voigt model used for calibration measurements, our model for the strain dynamics in the organoid does not consider the droplet’s capillary forces as a parallel spring element, as we could not observe any stiffening effect on the long term behaviour of the creep compliance. See Suppl. Fig. 3 for a comparison between the single springpot model and a springpot in parallel with a spring. While other models were considered (see Suppl. Fig. 4), the springpot is the simplest model for describing the data. We obtained values for the Young’s modulus and dynamic modulus from the parameters of the springpot model (β and cβ) following the example of [28], and applying numerical factors to relate the 1D tensile storage and loss modulus to the 3D Young’s modulus and dynamic viscosity, as was done previously[23].

sec.title: Calibration of applied stress
sec.p: To determine precisely how much stress was applied during a measurement in organoid tissue, for each day of organoid measurements we injected multiple droplets (typical diameters (85 ± 35) microns) of the same magnetic oil used in the organoid into a viscous standard (N190000, Lot no. 14101d, Cannon Instrument Company). To control the viscosity, the imaging chamber and sample were held at (37.0 ± 0.1)°C while calibration experiments were performed. We acquired fluorescence confocal time series of the droplet (1.5 second interval time) while introducing a magnetic stress, as described above, in the same manner as in the organoid. From these image series, we obtained strain versus time curves using our custom python-based GUI. We determined the magnitude of stress change σ and the time t0 corresponding to the change by modelling the droplet in viscous standard as a 1D Kelvin-Voigt material with spring kd and dashpot µ, as before[23]. In this 1D description, the magnetic stress reads σm = kdε where ε is the equilibrium droplet strain and the droplet spring constant kd=6γR[23, 47, 48]. Under a step change in stress from σ0 to σ0 + σ, we model the strain dynamics as ε(t)=εΔ(1−e−(t−t0)/τ)+ε0, where t0 is when the step change occurs, ε0 is the initial strain before t0, εΔ + ε0 is the final strain at equilibrium, and τ = 6ηR/5γ is the relaxation timescale set by the surrounding medium’s viscosity (η), the droplet radius (R), and the interfacial tension (γ)[49]. The timescale in our 1D model τ = µ/kd gives us the relationship between the dashpot µ and dynamic viscosity η as µ = (36/5)η. We obtained values for τ, t0, and εΔ by directly fitting the strain versus time data, and we measured the viscosity of N190000 at 37°C to be ηR = (214.5 ± 6.8) Pa·s (mean ± s.e.m.) using a rheometer (see Methods below), allowing us to measure kd and σ.

Compared to the rheometer data, the droplet technique shows very good agreement for materials with viscosities higher than those used for calibration; for example, testing with the Cannon Instrument Company N2700000 viscosity standard results in a relative error Δ¯wσ¯w of 4.3% (see Suppl. Fig. 2), where σ¯w=ΣiσiΔi2Σi1Δi2 is the weighted mean stress and Δ¯w=1Σi1Δi2 is the weighted standard deviation. The total error of the applied stress Δ¯ contains also the systematic error of the viscosity standard using Δ¯=Δ¯w2+Δη2, where Δη=δηησ¯w. When calibrating with N190000 at 37°C, the uncertainty in the viscosity from the rheometer measurement (δη/η = 3.2%) is usually the largest source of error. When considering uncertainties from the fit as well, a typical total relative error in the applied stress amounts to Δ¯/σ¯w=3.4%.

sec.title: Rheometer measurements
sec.p: The dynamic viscosity ηR of the viscous standards (Cannon Instrument Company) was determined using a shear plate rheometer (Kinexus Ultra+, Malvern Instruments Limited). We first performed frequency and amplitude sweeps to determine the range of frequencies and strains, respectively, where the viscosity remained constant. Then we performed the measurements at a constant frequency and strain that were 10 % smaller than the upper limits of these ranges. For each viscous standard we performed 3–5 measurements at 37°C that lasted between 485–515 seconds. Of each data set, the last data point was dropped and the remaining last 20 data points were averaged to obtain ηR. To test that this method yields accurate results of the standards’ viscosities, we also probed the standards N62000 and N190000 at 25°C to compare the results with the values given by the standards’ manufacturer for the lots used (Suppl. Table 1).

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We thank Timo Betz and Max Bi for stimulating discussions. We thank Ellen Sletten for providing the fluorinated dye. We thank Mythili Padavu, Georgii Volkov, Teresa Rogler, Vlasta Hadalin and Lena Glanz for support with the organoid culture. We thank Max Bi and Marie Lackmann for feedback on the manuscript. We thank Jacopo di Russo, Florian Huhnke and Joachim Spatz for their contribution in the early phase of the project. We thank Joachim Rädler for his support. This work was supported by the European Research Council (ERC) under the European Union’s Horizon 2020 research and innovation program (Grant Agreement No. 850691), the Center for NanoScience (CeNS) at the Ludwig-Maximilians-University (LMU), Munich, and the Munich Cluster for Systems Neurology (SyNergy). The work was supported by the Human Frontier Science Program (Grant No. 18807).

fn.p: E.R.S and F.S. conceived the research. R.J. cultured the mouse retina organoids. M.F., E.R.S and F.S. developed the analysis pipeline. E.R.S, M.F. and A.T.B. analyzed the data. E.R.S. and M.F. performed the droplet injection experiments and confocal imaging. A.T.B. and F.S. probed the viscous standards on the rheometer. R.J. performed the immuno-histochemistry. E.R.S. performed the statistical analysis. All authors contributed to the manuscript.

caption.title: Probing the mechanics of mammalian retina organoids in situ using ferrofluid droplets as mechanical actuators.
caption.p: a, Phase contrast and fluorescence microscopy images of retina organoids grown from mouse embryonic stem cells at days in vitro (DIV) 2, 9, and 18. Retina cells become visible as GFP is expressed under retina promoter Rx at DIV 9 and 18. b, Confocal microscopy images of a cryosectioned organoid fixed on DIV 25 showing, left to right, GFP, nuclear stain, and recoverin immunostain (See Suppl. Movie 1). c, Sketch showing the injection of fluorescent magnetically responsive oil droplets into retina tissue. d, Confocal and transmitted light images of a DIV 19 retina organoid with magnetic droplet after injection. e, Confocal microscopy images of droplet (magenta) embedded in retina tissue (green) before (left) and after (right) the onset of applied stress (See Suppl. Movie 2). The elliptical segmentation of the droplet is shown (yellow), with the lengths a and b of the minor and major semi-axes and the relative orientation of the ellipse, θ, with respect to the magnetic field. f, Plots of b/a and θ versus time demonstrate how the aspect ratio and orientation change with onset of stress (left). Together, b/a and θ determine the strain ε (right). Dashed line indicates initial strain ε0. g, The compliance J = (ε − ε0)/σ is plotted against time for the entire duration of applied stress (1 hour). σ = (371 ± 12) Pa (mean ± s.d., see Methods). Scale bars: a 200, b 50, d 200 (left), 50 (right), e 10, all in microns.

caption.title: Scale invariance of strain relaxation in developing mammalian retina.
caption.p: a, Creep compliance in the retina tissue of mouse organoids ranging from DIV 16 to 24 are plotted against time. Lines show power law fits to data using equation 3 (Methods). b, The scaling exponents β obtained from (a) plotted against DIV remain smaller than 0.5, indicating solid-like behaviour. Inset: cβ plotted against DIV indicating the magnitude of viscoelastic resistance to the actuation. In a and b, measurements from different rounds of culture are plotted with different shapes (diamond, square, or circle). In the diamond round, pairs of compliance measurements were taken for organoids on DIV 22 and 23. These paired measurements are plotted in empty markers, and the average of these values is plotted in a filled marker. Lines indicate average values across all organoids, and the bands indicate ± one standard deviation of the mean. Forc¯β, the geometric mean and standard deviation were used. c, The effective tensile storage modulus E¯′(ω)=c¯βωβ¯cos(π2β¯) (solid line) and loss modulus E′′(ω)=c¯βωβ¯sin(π2β¯) (dashed line) extrapolated across a range of frequencies. For select frequencies, the geometric average storage and loss moduli are plotted. The marker shape (x, n = 1; hexagon, n = 6; octogon, n = 8; star, n = 13.) indicates the number of organoids n represented in the data point. Each geometric average computed at frequency f reflects all measurements in which the maximal observation time tmax ≥ 1/f. Error bars indicate geometric standard error of the mean.

caption.title: Quantifying the mechanics of the cellular mircoenvironment during retina development.
caption.p: a, The development of neuroepithelial tissues, like the retina, requires force-driven nuclear and cellular rearrangements to transform from a pseudo-stratified epithelium into a laminated structure of different cell types[20, 21]. b, The dynamic viscosity η=536E′′ and c, Young’s modulus E=512E′ calculated from data in Figure 2 as a function of timescale τ = 2π/ω. Lines indicate geometric means ηGM and EGM. Bands indicate geometric standard deviation. n = 13 organoids.
